claim: The Gettysburg Address is a speech.

supporting.text: The Gettysburg Address was delivered orally by Abraham Lincoln, which is a defining characteristic of a speech.

attacks.text: The Gettysburg Address was delivered orally by Abraham Lincoln, which is a defining characteristic of a speech.
Oral delivery alone does not define a speech; written works can also be read aloud without being classified as speeches.
The Gettysburg Address is too brief to qualify as a speech; it is more accurately described as a short address or remarks.
The context and intent of the Gettysburg Address, being a formal public address, clearly classify it as a speech regardless of length.
Many historically recognized speeches are brief, such as Winston Churchill's 'Never was so much owed by so many to so few,' which is still considered a speech.
The definition of a speech includes any formal oral presentation to an audience, which the Gettysburg Address satisfies, regardless of whether written works can also be read aloud.
Churchill's example is not directly comparable because it was part of a longer speech, whereas the Gettysburg Address was standalone and exceptionally short.

supporting.text: The Gettysburg Address is a written document preserved in history, which could classify it more as a written address than a speech.

attacks.text: The Gettysburg Address is a written document preserved in history, which could classify it more as a written address than a speech.
The Gettysburg Address was delivered orally by Abraham Lincoln, fulfilling the primary criterion of a speech.
Historical records confirm it was spoken to an audience at a public event, which aligns with the definition of a speech.
The written preservation does not negate its original form as an oral delivery; many speeches are later transcribed.
The context of its delivery (a dedication ceremony) further supports its classification as a speech, regardless of its archival form.
Transcription is merely a method of preservation and does not redefine the medium of the original communication.

supporting.text: The Gettysburg Address follows the structure and brevity typical of speeches, with a clear beginning, middle, and end.

attacks.text: The Gettysburg Address follows the structure and brevity typical of speeches, with a clear beginning, middle, and end.
The Gettysburg Address lacks the spontaneous and interactive elements commonly found in speeches, making it more akin to a written address.
Many speeches are delivered extemporaneously, whereas the Gettysburg Address was carefully crafted and read from a script, which is not typical of most speeches.
Even though it was read from a script, the Gettysburg Address was delivered orally to an audience, which is a defining characteristic of a speech.
Many famous speeches, such as those by politicians and leaders, are also carefully crafted and read from scripts, yet they are still considered speeches.
Oral delivery alone does not necessarily make something a speech; other forms like poetry readings are also delivered orally but are not classified as speeches.
The context and intent of the Gettysburg Address differ from typical political speeches, as it was more of a dedication than a persuasive or informative speech.

supporting.text: Unlike impromptu speeches, the Gettysburg Address was carefully crafted and revised, making it more akin to a formal written statement.

attacks.text: Unlike impromptu speeches, the Gettysburg Address was carefully crafted and revised, making it more akin to a formal written statement.
The Gettysburg Address was delivered orally in a public setting, which is a defining characteristic of a speech.
The careful crafting and revision process does not negate its classification as a speech, as many famous speeches undergo similar preparation.
Oral delivery alone does not exclusively define a speech; written statements can also be delivered orally without being classified as speeches.
The level of preparation distinguishes it from typical speeches, which are often less meticulously crafted.
Even if written statements can be delivered orally, the context and intent of the Gettysburg Address align more closely with traditional speeches.

supporting.text: The Gettysburg Address was intended to be heard by an audience at a public event, which aligns with the traditional purpose of a speech.

attacks.text: The Gettysburg Address was intended to be heard by an audience at a public event, which aligns with the traditional purpose of a speech.
The Gettysburg Address was also written down and published, making it a written document as much as a speech.
The brevity and poetic nature of the Gettysburg Address make it more akin to a prose poem than a traditional speech.
Even if written down, the primary medium of delivery was oral, which is the defining characteristic of a speech.
Many speeches throughout history have been poetic or brief without ceasing to be speeches.
The written version has been more influential than the spoken delivery, suggesting its primary nature is as a document.

supporting.text: Historical records refer to the Gettysburg Address as a 'speech,' reinforcing its classification as such.

attacks.text: Historical records refer to the Gettysburg Address as a 'speech,' reinforcing its classification as such.
The term 'address' in its title suggests it may be more of a formal statement than a traditional speech.
Historical records can be inconsistent or subjective, and their classification may not be definitive.
The Gettysburg Address was delivered orally to an audience, which is a key characteristic of a speech.
Many formal statements are also delivered as speeches, so the terms are not mutually exclusive.
The consistency of historical records across multiple sources lends credibility to the classification as a speech.
Oral delivery alone does not define a speech; content and context are equally important.
If historical sources disagree or use varying terminology, their collective reliability is questionable.

supporting.text: The Gettysburg Address lacks interactive elements typical of speeches, such as audience engagement or Q&A, making it more like a proclamation.

attacks.text: The Gettysburg Address lacks interactive elements typical of speeches, such as audience engagement or Q&A, making it more like a proclamation.
The Gettysburg Address was delivered orally to an audience, which is a defining characteristic of a speech, regardless of interactivity.
Many historical speeches lack interactive elements due to their formal nature, yet they are still classified as speeches.
Oral delivery alone does not necessarily classify something as a speech; written proclamations can also be read aloud without being speeches.
The absence of interactivity in the Gettysburg Address distinguishes it from typical speeches and aligns it more with formal declarations.
The context and intent of the Gettysburg Address—to commemorate and inspire—are consistent with the purpose of many famous speeches, reinforcing its classification as such.
